t: Job 6
Job Replies: My Complaint Is Just
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Oh*pn that my vexation were weighed, and*ld all my calamity laid in the balances!
For*ln then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea; therefore*ld my words have been rash.
For*ln the arrows of the Almighty are in me; my*ld spirit drinks their poison; the*ld terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does*ln the wild donkey bray when he has grass, or*ld the ox low over his fodder?
Can*ln that which is tasteless be eaten without salt, or*ld is there any taste in the juice of the mallow?
My*ln appetite refuses to touch them; they*ld are as food that is loathsome to me.
“Oh*pn that I might have my request, and*ld that God would fulfill my hope,
that*ln it would please God to crush me, that*ld he would let loose his hand and cut me off!
This*ln would be my comfort; I*ld would even exult in pain unsparing, for*ld I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
What*ln is my strength, that I should wait? And*ld what is my end, that I should be patient?
Is*ln my strength the strength of stones, or is my flesh bronze?
Have*ln I any help in me, when*ld resource is driven from me?
“He*pn who withholds kindness from a friend forsakes*ld the fear of the Almighty.
My*ln brothers are treacherous as a torrent-bed, as*ld torrential streams that pass away,
which*ln are dark with ice, and*ld where the snow hides itself.
When*ln they melt, they disappear; when*ld it is hot, they vanish from their place.
The*ln caravans turn aside from their course; they*ld go up into the waste and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema look, the*ld travelers of Sheba hope.
They*ln are ashamed because they were confident; they*ld come there and are disappointed.
For*ln you have now become nothing; you*ld see my calamity and are afraid.
Have*ln I said, ‘Make me a gift’? Or,*ld ‘From your wealth offer a bribe for me’?
Or,*ln ‘Deliver me from the adversary’s hand’? Or,*ld ‘Redeem me from the hand of the ruthless’?
“Teach*pn me, and I will be silent; make*ld me understand how I have gone astray.
How*ln forceful are upright words! But*ld what does reproof from you reprove?
Do*ln you think that you can reprove words, when*ld the speech of a despairing man is wind?
You*ln would even cast lots over the fatherless, and*ld bargain over your friend.
“But*pn now, be pleased to look at me, for*ld I will not lie to your face.
Please*ln turn; let no injustice be done. Turn*ld now; my vindication is at stake.
Is*ln there any injustice on my tongue? Cannot*ld my palate discern the cause of calamity?
